case_vignette: A 25-year-old male presents with 2 years of pruriginous erythematous plaques with silver scales on elbows, knees and buttocks. He says that his father is known for hand and back arthritis. He denies personal and family history of dermatology conditions and atopy. Physical exam reveals pitting on all 10 fingernails.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been dealing with itchy, red patches with silvery scales on my elbows, knees, and buttocks for the past two years.
Is this itchiness accompanied by any pain or burning sensation?
No, it's just really itchy.
What is your age and sex?
I'm a 25-year-old male.
Have you been diagnosed with any underlying medical conditions or are you currently taking any medications?
No, I haven't been diagnosed with any skin issues or allergies, and I'm not on any medications.

Does anyone in your family have a history of similar symptoms?

**Final Diagnosis:** Psoriasis

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A 25-year-old male patient has been dealing with itchy, red patches with silvery scales on his elbows, knees, and buttocks for the past two years. The patient has not been diagnosed with any skin issues or allergies, and is not on any medications.
trial_0.vignette_mcq: Psoriasis vulgaris. The patient's symptoms, including pruritic erythematous plaques with silver scales on elbows, knees, and buttocks, and pitting of the nails, are consistent with psoriasis. The presence of a family history of arthritis also supports this diagnosis. Atopic dermatitis typically presents with an itchy rash in infancy or early childhood, and seborrheic dermatitis usually affects the scalp, face, and other oily areas. Lichen planus typically presents with purpuric papules or plaques, and does not typically involve the nails.
